translated: The Netti
The Paṭiniddesa Section
The Vibhaṅga
The Vibhaṅga on the Food for Spiritual Power
Herein, what is the food for spiritual power?
The verse “The satisfaction, the danger, the escape” is the food for spiritual power.
What does it teach?

original: Assādaṁ ādīnavaṁ nissaraṇaṁ phalaṁ upāyaṁ āṇattiṁ.
analyzed: assādam ādīnavam nissaraṇam phalam upāyam āṇatti
translated: Satisfaction, danger, escape, fruit, means, injunction.

original: “Dhammaṁ vo, bhikkhave, desessāmi ādikalyāṇaṁ majjhekalyāṇaṁ pariyosānakalyāṇaṁ sātthaṁ sabyañjanaṁ kevalaparipuṇṇaṁ parisuddhaṁ brahmacariyaṁ pakāsessāmī”ti.
analyzed: dhammam vaḥ bhikkhave desessāmi ādi kalyāṇam majjhe kalyāṇam pariyosāna kalyāṇam sa attham sa byañjanam kevala paripuṇṇam parisuddham brahmacariyam pakāsessāmi iti
translated: “Bhikkhus, I will teach you a spiritual power that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, with its own meaning, with its own phrasing, that is complete, pure, and perfect. I will reveal a spiritual life that is fulfilled.”
Herein, what is satisfaction?
“When one who desires gains what he desires,
and his mind is satisfied,
then he is happy,

analyzed: laddhā mad caḥ yat icchati iti
translated: having obtained what he wished for.”
This is satisfaction.
Herein, what is danger?
“When one who desires does not gain what he desires,
and his mind is not satisfied,
then his desires desert him,
as if he were pierced by a dart.”
This is danger.
Herein, what is the escape?
“One who avoids desires,
like a snake’s head,
the pleasant and varied world,
he is mindful, he overcomes it.”
This is the escape.
Herein, what is the gratification?

analyzed: khettam vatthum hiraññam vā  gavāssam dāsa porisa
translated: “A field, a site, gold or silver,🔽a cow, a bullock, a horse, a slave,
women, various desires,
a man who is attached to these.”
This is the gratification.
Herein, what is the danger?
“The weak are overpowered by the strong,
he is devoured by his troubles,
then suffering follows him,
like water a boat that is broken.”
This is the danger.
Herein, what is the escape?
“Therefore a person who is always mindful
should avoid desires,
having given them up he crosses over the flood,
like one who has crossed over the ocean by boat.”
This is the escape.
Herein, what is the fruit?
“The Dhamma protects the one who lives by the Dhamma,
like a great umbrella in the rainy season;
This is the benefit of the Dhamma that is well-practiced,

analyzed: na duggatim gacchati dhamma cārī iti
translated: the one who lives by the Dhamma does not go to a bad destination.”
This is the fruit.
Herein, what is the method?
“All conditioned things are impermanent,”
“All conditioned things are suffering,”
“All things are not-self:🔽
“When by understanding one sees all things as not-self,
then one turns away from suffering.
This is the way to purity.”
This is the means.
Herein, what is the Injunction?
“As one with eyes can shun a path🔽that leads to a pit,
so the wise one in the world of life
shuns evil deeds.”
This is the Injunction.
Herein, what is the Fruit?
“Contemplate the world as void,
Mogharaja, is the Injunction;
‘Always mindful’ is the means.
‘Having shaken off the view of self,
thus one can cross over death.’
This is the Fruit.

original: Tattha bhagavā ugghaṭitaññussa puggalassa nissaraṇaṁ desayati, vipañcitaññussa puggalassa
analyzed: tattha bhagavā ugghaṭita ññussa puggalassa nissaraṇam desayati vipañcita ññussa puggalassa
translated: Herein, the Blessed One teaches the escape for the person of quick understanding,🔽and for the person of slow understanding he teaches the unsatisfactoriness and the escape.

original: ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca desayati, neyyassa puggalassa assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca desayati.
analyzed: ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca desayati neyyassa puggalassa assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca desayati
translated: For the person of average understanding he teaches the gratification, the unsatisfactoriness, and the escape.
Herein, there are four Ways and four Persons.

original: Taṇhācarito mando satindriyena dukkhāya paṭipadāya dandhābhiññāya niyyāti satipaṭṭhānehi nissayehi.
analyzed: taṇhā caritaḥ mando sati indriyena dukkhāya paṭipadāya dandha abhiññāya niyyāti sati paṭṭhānehi nissayehi
translated: The faith-follower of duller direct-knowledge and keen faculties goes forth by the way of suffering with sluggish direct-knowledge by means of the foundations of mindfulness.

original: Taṇhācarito udattho samādhindriyena dukkhāya paṭipadāya khippābhiññāya niyyāti jhānehi nissayehi.🔽Diṭṭhicarito mando vīriyindriyena sukhāya paṭipadāya dandhābhiññāya niyyāti sammappadhānehi nissayehi.🔽Diṭṭhicarito udatto paññindriyena sukhāya paṭipadāya khippābhiññāya niyyāti saccehi nissayehi.
analyzed: taṇhā caritaḥ udattho samādhi indriyena dukkhāya paṭipadāya khippa abhiññāya niyyāti jhānehi nissayehi  diṭṭhi caritaḥ mandaḥ vīriya indriyena sukhāya paṭipadāya dandha abhiññāya niyyāti sammappadhānehi nissayehi  diṭṭhi caritaḥ udattaḥ paññindriyena sukhāya paṭipadāya khippa abhiññāya niyyāti saccehi nissayehi
translated: The faith-follower of keener direct-knowledge and dull faculties goes forth by the way of suffering with swift direct-knowledge by means of the jhanas.🔽The Dhamma-follower of duller direct-knowledge and keen faculties goes forth by the way of happiness with sluggish direct-knowledge by means of the right endeavours.🔽The Dhamma-follower of keener direct-knowledge and dull faculties goes forth by the way of happiness with swift direct-knowledge by means of the truths.

original: Ubho taṇhācaritā samathapubbaṅgamāya vipassanāya niyyanti rāgavirāgāya cetovimuttiyā.
analyzed: ubho taṇhā caritā samatha pubbaṅgamāya vipassanāya niyyanti rāga virāgāya cetaḥ vimuttiyā
translated: Both the faith-follower and the Dhamma-follower of duller direct-knowledge go forth by insight preceded by quiet by means of the faculties and the powers.

original: Ubho diṭṭhicaritā vipassanāpubbaṅgamena samathena niyyanti avijjāvirāgāya paññāvimuttiyā.
analyzed: ubho diṭṭhi caritā vipassanā pubbaṅgamena samathena niyyanti avijjā virāgāya paññā vimuttiyā
translated: Both the faith-follower and the Dhamma-follower of keener direct-knowledge go forth by quiet preceded by insight by means of the enlightenment factors.

original: Tattha ye samathapubbaṅgamāhi paṭipadāhi niyyanti, te nandiyāvaṭṭena nayena hātabbā, ye vipassanāpubbaṅgamāhi paṭipadāhi niyyanti, te sīhavikkīḷitena nayena hātabbā.
analyzed: tattha ye samatha pubbaṅgamāhi paṭipadāhi niyyanti te nandiyāvaṭṭena nayena hātabbā ye vipassanā pubbaṅgamāhi paṭipadāhi niyyanti te sīhavikkīḷitena nayena hātabbā
translated: Herein, those who go forth by the way beginning with serenity are to be converted by the method of the Thread dealing with the round of rebirths beginning with “Birth is suffering” , while those who go forth by the way beginning with insight are to be converted by the method of the Thread dealing with the round of rebirths beginning with “In dependence on ignorance formations come to be” .

original: Svāyaṁ hāro kattha sambhavati, yassa satthā vā dhammaṁ desayati aññataro vā garuṭṭhānīyo sabrahmacārī, so taṁ dhammaṁ sutvā saddhaṁ paṭilabhati.🔽Tattha yā vīmaṁsā ussāhanā tulanā upaparikkhā, ayaṁ sutamayī paññā.
analyzed: su ayam hāro kattha sambhavati yassa satthā vā dhammam desayati aññataraḥ vā garuṭṭhānīyaḥ sabrahmacārī so tam dhammam sutvā saddham paṭilabhati  tattha yā vīmasā ussāhanā tulanā upaparikkhā ayam suta mayī paññā
translated: Now, where does this Conversion come about? When either the Master or a distinguished co-resident teaches the True Idea, then on hearing that True Idea he acquires faith.🔽Herein, the investigation, the inquiry, the scrutiny, is understanding consisting in what is heard.

original: Tathā sutena nissayena yā vīmaṁsā tulanā upaparikkhā manasānupekkhaṇā, ayaṁ cintāmayī paññā.
analyzed: tathā sutena nissayena yā vīmasā tulanā upaparikkhā manasā anupekkhaṇā ayam cintā mayī paññā
translated: And the investigation, inquiry, scrutiny, with the support of what is heard, is understanding consisting in cogitation.

original: Imāhi dvīhi paññāhi manasikārasampayuttassa yaṁ ñāṇaṁ uppajjati dassanabhūmiyaṁ vā bhāvanābhūmiyaṁ vā, ayaṁ bhāvanāmayī paññā.🔽Paratoghosā sutamayī paññā.
analyzed: imāhi dvīhi paññāhi manasikāra sampayuttassa yam ñāṇam uppajjati dassana bhūmiyam vā bhāvanā bhūmiyam vā ayam bhāvanā mayī paññā  paratoghosā suta mayī paññā
translated: The knowledge that arises in one who is associated with these two kinds of understanding in the plane of seeing and in the plane of development is understanding consisting in keeping in being.🔽Understanding consisting in what is heard is that consisting in what is learnt from others’ voices.

analyzed: paccatta samuṭṭhitā yonisas manasikārā cintā mayī paññā
translated: Understanding consisting in cogitation is that consisting in one’s own choice after one has learnt from others’ voices.

original: Yaṁ parato ca ghosena paccattasamuṭṭhitena ca yonisomanasikārena ñāṇaṁ uppajjati, ayaṁ bhāvanāmayī paññā.
analyzed: yam paratas ca ghosena paccatta samuṭṭhitena ca yoniso manasikārena ñāṇam uppajjati ayam bhāvanā mayī paññā
translated: And when knowledge arises through the other’s voice and through the application of thought, this is understanding consisting in development.

original: Yassa imā dve paññā atthi sutamayī cintāmayī ca, ayaṁ ugghaṭitaññū.🔽Yassa sutamayī paññā atthi, cintāmayī natthi, ayaṁ vipañcitaññū.
analyzed: yassa imā dve paññā atthi suta mayī cintā mayī ca ayam ugghaṭita ññū  yassa suta mayī paññā atthi cintā mayī na atthi ayam
translated: He who has these two kinds of understanding, consisting in what is learnt and in cogitation, is a person of penetrating knowledge.🔽He who has understanding consisting in what is learnt but not that consisting in cogitation is a person of confirmed opinion.

original: Yassa neva sutamayī paññā atthi na cintāmayī, ayaṁ neyyo.
analyzed: yassa nā iva suta mayī paññā atthi na cintā mayī ayam neyyaḥ
translated: He who has neither understanding consisting in what is learnt nor that consisting in cogitation is one to be trained.
What does this teaching of the Dhamma teach?

original: Cattāri saccāni dukkhaṁ samudayaṁ nirodhaṁ maggaṁ.
analyzed: cattāri saccāni dukkham samudayam nirodham magga
translated: It teaches the Four Noble Truths, namely, suffering, origination, cessation, and the path.

original: Ādīnavo ca phalañca dukkhaṁ, assādo samudayo, nissaraṇaṁ nirodho, upāyo āṇatti ca maggo.
analyzed: ādīnavaḥ ca phalam ca dukkha assādaḥ samudayaḥ nissaraṇam nirodho upāyaḥ āṇatti ca maggo
translated: The danger and the fruit are suffering; the satisfaction is origination; the escape is cessation; the means is the path.
These are the Four Noble Truths.
This is the Wheel of the Dhamma.
As the Blessed One said:

original: “idaṁ dukkhan”ti me, bhikkhave, bārāṇasiyaṁ isipatane migadāye anuttaraṁ dhammacakkaṁ
analyzed: idam dukkhanti me bhikkhave bārāṇasiyam isipatane migadāye anuttaram dhamma cakka
translated: “Bhikkhus, at Bārāṇasī, in the Deer Park at Isipatana, I set rolling the matchless Wheel of the Dhamma which is thrice-revolved and twelve-fold.

original: pavattitaṁ appaṭivattiyaṁ samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena vā brahmunā
analyzed: pavattitam appaṭivattiyam samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena vā brahmunā
translated: And this Wheel of the Dhamma, which has been set rolling by me, cannot be rolled back by any recluse or brahmin or god or Māra or Brahmā or by anyone in the world.”

original: vā kenaci vā lokasmiṁ, sabbaṁ dhammacakkaṁ.
analyzed: vā kenacid vā lokasmi sabbam dhammacakka
translated: and by anyone in the world, is the Wheel of the Dhamma.

original: Tattha aparimāṇā padā, aparimāṇā akkharā, aparimāṇā byañjanā, aparimāṇā ākārā neruttā niddesā.
analyzed: tattha aparimāṇā padāḥ aparimāṇāḥ akkharāḥ aparimāṇāḥ byañjanāḥ aparimāṇāḥ ākārāḥ neruttāḥ niddesā
translated: Herein, there are immeasurable words, immeasurable syllables, immeasurable letters, immeasurable modes, and immeasurable descriptions.

original: Etasseva atthassa saṅkāsanā pakāsanā vivaraṇā vibhajanā uttānīkammaṁ paññatti, itipidaṁ dukkhaṁ ariyasaccaṁ.🔽“Ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo”ti me, bhikkhave, bārāṇasiyaṁ isipatane migadāye anuttaraṁ dhammacakkaṁ pavattitaṁ …pe…🔽“ayaṁ dukkhanirodho”ti me, bhikkhave …pe…
analyzed: etassa iva atthassa saṅkāsanā pakāsanā vivaraṇā vibhajanā uttānīkammam paññatti iti pidam dukkham ariya sacca  ayam dukkha samudayaḥ ti me bhikkhave bārāṇasiyam isipatane migadāye anuttaram dhammacakkam pavattitam pe  ayam dukkha nirodho ti me bhikkhave pe
translated: The pointing out, the revealing, the making known, the setting forth, the opening up, the explaining, and the revealing of this meaning is the description. Thus this Noble Truth of Suffering is.🔽“Bhikkhus, at Baranasi, in the Deer Park at Isipatana, I set rolling the Wheel of the Dhamma, which is threefold and possesses the twelve factors, and which leads to the stilling of suffering.🔽“Bhikkhus, at Baranasi, in the Deer Park at Isipatana, I set rolling the Wheel of the Dhamma, which is threefold and possesses the twelve factors, and which leads to the stilling of suffering.

original: “ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā”ti me, bhikkhave, bārāṇasiyaṁ isipatane migadāye🔽anuttaraṁ dhammacakkaṁ pavattitaṁ appaṭivattiyaṁ samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena
analyzed: ayam dukkha nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ati me bhikkhave bārāṇasiyam isipatane migadāye  anuttaram dhammacakkam pavattitam appaṭivattiyam samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena
translated: “Bhikkhus, at Baranasi, in the Deer Park at Isipatana, I set rolling the Wheel of the Dhamma, which is threefold and possesses the twelve factors, and which leads to the stilling of suffering.

original: vā mārena vā brahmunā vā kenaci vā lokasmiṁ.
analyzed: vā mārena vā brahmunā vā kenacid vā
translated: and which no recluse or brahmin or god or Mara or Brahma or anyone else in the world can set rolling.

original: Tattha aparimāṇā padā, aparimāṇā akkharā, aparimāṇā byañjanā, aparimāṇā ākārā neruttā niddesā.
analyzed: tattha aparimāṇā padāḥ aparimāṇāḥ akkharāḥ aparimāṇāḥ byañjanāḥ aparimāṇāḥ ākārāḥ neruttāḥ niddesā
translated: Herein, there are innumerable words, innumerable syllables, innumerable inflections, innumerable modes of expression, innumerable etymologies, and innumerable definitions.

original: Etasseva atthassa saṅkāsanā pakāsanā vivaraṇā vibhajanā uttānīkammaṁ paññatti itipidaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā ariyasaccaṁ.
analyzed: etassa iva atthassa saṅkāsanā pakāsanā vivaraṇā vibhajanā uttānīkammam paññatti dukkha nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ariya sacca
translated: This Noble Truth of the Way Leading to the Cessation of Suffering is the Noble Truth of the Way Leading to the Cessation of Suffering.

original: Tattha bhagavā akkharehi saṅkāseti, padehi pakāseti, byañjanehi vivarati, ākārehi vibhajati, niruttīhi uttānīkaroti, niddesehi paññapeti.
analyzed: tattha bhagavā akkharehi saṅkāseti padehi pakāseti byañjanehi vivarati ākārehi vibhajati niruttīhi uttānīkaroti niddesehi paññapeti
translated: Herein, the Blessed One elucidates by means of syllables, elucidates by means of words, elucidates by means of inflections, elucidates by means of modes of expression, elucidates by means of etymologies, and elucidates by means of definitions.

original: Tattha bhagavā akkharehi ca padehi ca ugghaṭeti, byañjanehi ca ākārehi ca vipañcayati, niruttīhi ca niddesehi ca vitthāreti.
analyzed: tattha bhagavā akkharehi ca padehi ca ugghaṭeti byañjanehi ca ākārehi ca vipañcayati niruttīhi ca niddesehi ca vitthāreti
translated: Herein, the Blessed One elucidates by means of syllables and words, elucidates by means of inflections and modes of expression, elucidates by means of etymologies and definitions.

original: Tattha ugghaṭanā ādi, vipañcanā majjhe, vitthāraṇā pariyosānaṁ.
analyzed: tattha ugghaṭanā ādi vipañcanā majjhe vitthāraṇā pariyosāna
translated: Herein, elucidation is the beginning, elucidation is the middle, elucidation is the end.

original: Soyaṁ dhammavinayo ugghaṭīyanto ugghaṭitaññūpuggalaṁ vineti, tena naṁ āhu “ādikalyāṇo”ti.
analyzed: saḥ ayam dhamma vinayaḥ ugghaṭīyantaḥ ugghaṭita ññū puggalam vineti tena nam āhu ādi kalyāṇaḥ ti
translated: This Dhamma and Discipline is elucidated, and the person who knows the elucidated is trained. Therefore it is said, “It is good in the beginning.”

original: Vipañcīyanto vipañcitaññūpuggalaṁ vineti, tena naṁ āhu “majjhekalyāṇo”ti.
analyzed: vipañcīyantaḥ vipañcita ñū puggalam vinā iti tena naṃ āhu majjhe kalyāṇaḥ ti
translated: He trains the person who is a thinker by thinking out, and so they say of him that he is good in the middle.

original: Vitthārīyanto neyyaṁ puggalaṁ vineti, tena naṁ āhu “pariyosānakalyāṇo”ti.🔽Tattha chappadāni attho saṅkāsanā pakāsanā vivaraṇā vibhajanā uttānīkammaṁ paññatti, imāni chappadāni attho.
analyzed: vitthārīyantaḥ na iyyam puggalam vinā iti tena nam āhu pariyosāna kalyāṇā iti  tattha chappadāni attho saṅkāsanā pakāsanā vivaraṇā vibhajanā uttānīkammam paññatti imāni chappadāni attho
translated: He trains the person who is a wanderer by wandering out, and so they say of him that he is good at the end.🔽Herein, the six terms “meaning,” “encouraging,” “expounding,” “elucidating,” “analyzing,” and “bringing to sight” are the meaning.

original: Chappadāni byañjanaṁ akkharaṁ padaṁ byañjanaṁ ākāro nirutti niddeso, imāni chappadāni byañjanaṁ.
analyzed: chappadāni byañjanam akkharam padam byañjanam ākāraḥ nirutti niddesaḥ imāni chappadāni byañjana
translated: The six terms “text,” “letter,” “word,” “text,” “mode,” “dialect,” and “definition” are the phrasing.

original: Tenāha bhagavā “dhammaṁ vo, bhikkhave, desessāmi ādikalyāṇaṁ majjhekalyāṇaṁ pariyosānakalyāṇaṁ sātthaṁ sabyañjanan”ti.
analyzed: tena āha bhagavā dhammam vaḥ bhikkhave desessāmi ādi kalyāṇam majjhe kalyāṇam pariyosāna kalyāṇam sa attham sa byañjananti
translated: That is why the Blessed One said: “Bhikkhus, I will teach you the Dhamma that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, with its meaning, with its phrasing, with its message, with the message fully unfolded” .

original: Kevalanti lokuttaraṁ, na missaṁ lokiyehi dhammehi.🔽Paripuṇṇanti paripūraṁ anūnaṁ anatirekaṁ.
analyzed: kevalanti lokuttara na missam lokiyehi dhammehi  paripuṇṇanti paripūram anūnam an atireka
translated: Complete: supramundane, not mixed with mundane states.🔽Perfect: fulfilled, not deficient, not incomplete.

original: Parisuddhanti nimmalaṁ sabbamalāpagataṁ pariyodātaṁ upaṭṭhitaṁ sabbavisesānaṁ, idaṁ
analyzed: parisuddham ti nimmalam sabba mala apagatam pariyodātam upaṭṭhitam
translated: Pure: stainless, rid of all defilements, bright, manifest in all its aspects. This is

original: vuccati tathāgatapadaṁitipi tathāgatanisevitaṁitipi tathāgatārañjitaṁitipi, ato cetaṁ
analyzed: vuccati tathāgata pada etipi tathāgata nisevita etipi tathāgata ārañjita etipi
translated: and it is called the Tathagata’s way, the Tathagata’s resort, the Tathagata’s domain.
And from this it is evident that this is the holy life.

analyzed: tena āha bhagavā kevala paripuṇṇam parisuddham brahmacariyam pakāsessāmi iti
translated: That is why the Blessed One said: “I will teach you, monks, a holy life that is complete in all its aspects, pure in its entirety.”
For whom is this teaching of the Dhamma? For meditators.

analyzed: tena āha mahākaccāyano  as sāda ādīnavatā
translated: That is why the venerable Maha Kaccana said:

analyzed: nissaraṇam pi ca phalam upāyaḥ ca
translated: “The meditator who sees satisfaction, Discontent, escape, and fruit,
And the method, and the Master’s word,
Has found the nourishment for insight.”
The nourishment for insight is defined.
